abstract: Investigators are having a hard time determining what made Germanwings co-pilot Andreas Lubitz deliberately crash plane into French Alps since there are so few instances of this, although 'aircraft-assisted pilot suicide,' as it is known, is not without precedent.
lead_paragraph: If Andreas Lubitz, the flight’s 27-year-old co-pilot, was determined to kill himself, he would not be the first to use an airplane as a tool for self-destruction or to kill passengers and other crew members in the process.

headline.main: Suicide by Plane Crash Is Rare but Not Without Precedent
headline.print_headline: Suicide by Plane Crash Is Not Without Precedent

snippet: If Andreas Lubitz, the flight’s 27-year-old co-pilot, was determined to kill himself, he would not be the first to use an airplane as a tool for self-destruction or to kill passengers and other crew members in the process.
